forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content: Well, that hypothetical software WON'T be a "RAMdisK", but rather a "DiskRAM" :wink:. You are probably thinking of this (or something similar): [http://www.instructa...as-virtual-RAM/](http://www.instructables.com/id/Use-your-USB-flash-drive-as-virtual-RAM/ "External link") [http://www.wikihow.c...en-Drive-As-RAM](http://www.wikihow.com/Use-Pen-Drive-As-RAM "External link") [http://www.ehow.com/...ory-ram-xp.html](http://www.ehow.com/how_6054256_use-usb-memory-ram-xp.html "External link") That is (was), together with ReadyBoost: [http://www.howtogeek...st-worth-using/](http://www.howtogeek.com/123780/htg-explains-is-readyboost-worth-using/ "External link") one of the silliest things that you could do (remember that it was "invented" in times of USB 2.0 and Vista ![:ph34r:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)). With USB 3.0 it may make some (very little) sense, but ONLY if you are "desperately" needing some more RAM than you actually have on the motherboard (or can have). The Rule of the Thumb is easy and "linear": * If you need more RAM, add more RAM. Think a bit about it, you are missing \*some quantity\* of \*something\* that is working with transfer/read/write speeds in the order of magnitude of 3 up to 13 Gb/s and you want to replace this \*something\* with \*something else\* that had (USB 2.0 typical stick) 20 Mb/s and may have (FAST USB 3.0 stick) 120 Mb/s. ![:w00t:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif) ![:cheers:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: alacran
forumNotes.content:
Absolutely agree you can't supplant RAM with such an inferior speed device as an USB stick, but you may reduce writing to HDD and get some plus.

I tested once eBoostr on XP on an old Pentium IV 3.0 GHZ, 1 GB RAM DDR 1 pc-400, 160GB IDE HDD 7200 RPM (defragmented), using a 4 GB USB 2.0 stick NTFS formated, 1 GB of RAM is enough for XP but I just wanted to see if there was a way to improve booting, so using eBoostr to designate the USB stick to work with, prefetch and pagefiles were allocated there and I got a better booting time (maybe 5 or 6 seconds less, don't remember exactly how much) perhaps only because the HDD was mainly reading info during booting and almost all writes were done on USB stick, any way latter it went back to usual as I needed the USB stick for some thing else.

Actually some close to this approach it's been done using rotatory HDD for the main system and solid HDD for some files as hibernate and maybe pagefile and some more I don't know, but I am sure our friend Wonko can give us more info about this

Best Regards

Well, in this case **Wonko** won' t help much ![:w00t:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif), as he is a convinced believer in:

* calling things with their names
* use things for what they are (and for their intended use)

Specifically, when it comes to hibernate ![:ph34r:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif), Wonko reads it as "something that either won't work or that will work just until it will break, and it will break soon and it will cause havoc", the rule of thumb is "never use hibernate features, unless you are looking for troubles".

When it comes to pagefile, it is even worse (in Wonko's *perverted* mind), pagefile is a lousy workaround to having not enough RAM, it makes no sense whatsoever on machines with "enough" RAM, it is only useful for "programmed/intentional" crashdumps, otherwise it is either unneeded or a simple way to delay a crash (or in case of serious crash to really mess with the underlying filesystem, if set to "dynamic").

The fact that some lousy software (namely, as an example, Adobe Photoshop) actually "wants" a pagefile could be the ONLY reason on a ++properly++ RAM equipped machine to have a pagefile.

Of course the above is the short version, the "long" version was already given here:

[http://reboot.pro/to...e-2#entry169634](http://reboot.pro/topic/18245-creating-and-installing-win7togo-booting-running-windows-7/page-2#entry169634 "")

if you need some more detail, ask.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Well, this has been tallked already to death. ![:frusty:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/frusty.gif)

99.99% (please read as "all") USB sticks will come form factory set as "Removable".

You can EITHER "flip the removable bit" with the specific manufacturer tool or install in the OS a filter driver, of which we have three different implementation:

1. cfadisk
2. dummydisk
3. diskmod

the last one being the "most complete" as besides the "Removable vs. Fixed" allows to make a USB device "internal", or "whatever" is needed to have a page file on it and have Windows Update working.

Now you have all the needed keywords to search for the relevant info/programs.

:cheers.

Wonko
